title: 30+ Pain Management Strategies (Lower Back Pain, Arthritis) - SelfDecode Supplements
author: Jasmine Foster
description: Millions of people live with pain every day. Are you among them? Read on to learn evidence-based strategies for pain control.
cleaned_text: Millions of people live with painful chronic disorders that reduce their quality of life. Are you among them? Read on to learn evidence-based strategies for many types of pain control. If you have persistent or unexplained pain, it is important to discuss these concerns with your doctor. The information in this post is presented for educational purposes only, and should not be used to replace standard medical care. Conventional Treatments for Pain These are some of the treatments your doctor may prescribe for [pain](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/23-ways-to-combat-pain-naturally-by-increasing-your-opioids/). We recommend against taking any medication without talking to your doctor, especially if your pain is persistent or unexplained. Physiotherapy Pain may not necessarily correlate with the degree of physical damage. However, poor movement patterns and imbalances may cause the body to reduce further harm to itself by causing pain [ [1](http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1179/108331907X223010)]. [Exercise](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/top-14-proven-health-benefits-exercise-references-mechanisms/) and movements help ensure that injuries heal in a way that restores functional ability [ [2](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7779328)]. Lack of movements can reduce mobility and strength after the injuries heal. Physical therapy involves [ [3](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24846036), [4](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15062718)]: - Exercise: For some patients, exercise can help manage pain. It strengthens bones and muscles, and improves mood, [self-esteem](https://selfhacked.com/blog/should-we-be-building-our-self-esteem/), physical capacity, and decreases [stress](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/63-factors-raising-stress-cortisol-level-backed-science/)[ [5](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11783835)]. - Corrective movements, such as strengthening muscles around the injured areas, improving postures, and correcting poor movement patterns, can help reduce pain [ [6](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4499985/)]. - Massage therapy reduced pain sensitivity at tender points by relaxing muscle tissues and also reduces stress by increasing [oxytocin](https://selfhacked.com/blog/the-social-chilled-out-and-empathetic-genes-oxytocin-receptor-snps/)[ [7](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3018656/)]. - Education and advice can help individuals understand their condition and make the best decisions addressing their issues [ [8](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92522/)]. - Mobility aids can assist in a patient's balance and maintain motor functions [ [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2231545/)]. Physiotherapy should be carefully overseen by a medical professional. Painkillers Painkillers help with mild-to-moderate acute pain by treating the symptoms. These include Tylenol or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Medication choice depends on the condition and risk factors of the patients. Some (cyclooxygenase-2 selective) NSAIDs can cause heart complications [ [10](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23939498)]. NSAIDs can reduce inflammation thus helping with pain. These drugs also reduce fever (antipyretic effects). These drugs include [ [11](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17612044)]: - Aspirin - Ibuprofen - Naproxen - Phenylbutazone NSAIDs do have side effects, such as reducing the protective layers in the gut, which can cause stomach ulcers and increase intestinal permeability. In injuries, actively reducing inflammation may also prolong healing time [ [12](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3890944/), [13](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1727292/), [14](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23662318)]. Strategies that May Help Manage Pain Studied for General Pain Likely Effective 1. Camphor Camphor is a compound that can be distilled from the bark and wood of the camphor tree or produced from turpentine oil. Camphor relieves pain by activating the TRPV1 and TRPV3 channels while blocking TRPA1. Topical preparations with 3-11% camphor are approved by the FDA for pain related to [cold](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/12-reasons-embrace-cold/) sores, insect stings and bites, burns, and hemorrhoids [ [15](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17873595/), [16](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17970723/), [17](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8008522/)]. In a small trial on 20 people, a topical spray with camphor, menthol, and the essential oils of eucalyptus, clove, turpentine, and Gaultheria relieved mild to moderate pain from different conditions when applied on the joints, shoulders, and back [ [18](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25553684/)]. Topical phenol-camphor relieved pain from lung inflammation in an old trial on 82 people [ [19](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/809376/)]. In mice and rats, a plant extract composed of linalool and camphor relieved pain from heat, irritation with acetic acid, and inflammation [ [20](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25973506/)]. Importantly, camphor should never be used at concentrations above 11%, ingested, or applied on open wounds because it can cause poisoning [ [21](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28363129/)]. 2. Capsicum [Capsaicin](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/capsaicin/) is the compound that makes chilli peppers hot. In the brain cells, capsaicin activates the TRPV1 receptor. Although this protein triggers inflammatory pain, its repeated stimulation makes brain cells insensitive to pain perception. Capsaicin also seems to reduce the levels of [substance P](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/substance-p-roles/), which is involved in pain transmission, in the spinal cord [ [22](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5326624/), [23](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2581820/)]. Multiple studies show that topical creams and patches with 8% capsaicin are as effective as some oral painkillers at relieving pain caused by nerve damage, such as from HIV, herpes, and diabetes [ [24](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6464756/), [25](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23707278/), [26](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6956009/), [27](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21753727/), [28](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28365034/)]. Applied through the nose, capsaicin reduced the number and severity of cluster headache attacks in 3 small trials on 89 people [ [29](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2520386/), [30](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7708405/), [31](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8495452/)]. 3. Applied Heat or Cold Cold exposure (e.g., with ice packs) is commonly used to reduce swelling and pain after traumatic injuries. It may also help reduce the pain and need for opioid medication after surgical procedures such as knee replacement and jaw or cruciate ligament reconstruction. The evidence is more limited in the case of pain after wise tooth removal water is moderately effective in the prevention and recovery of muscle soreness after exercise [ [40](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4802003/), [41](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4586380/)]. Cold therapy has also been used in the treatment of [migraines](http://selfhacked.com/blog/natural-treatment-migraines/) for over 150 years. Different devices applying cold to the head and neck have been successfully tested in several clinical trials [ [42](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3941818/), [43](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3243707/), [44](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2584002/), [45](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11975819/), [46](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1697736/), [47](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3727573/)]. Both heat and cold have been reported to provide a small, short-term reduction of low-back pain when superficially applied. However, the evidence to support the use of these practices is limited. Similarly, a reduced number of trials suggests that applied heat or cold may help prevent perineal trauma after childbirth [ [48](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16437495/), [49](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4225921/), [50](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31238205/), [51](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22592710/)]. Applied heat also seems effective at relieving the pain from menstrual cramps, possibly by increasing blood flow, but the evidence is based on relatively few, small trials [ [52](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6214933/)]. Possibly Effective 4. Caffeine According to multiple studies, the addition of [caffeine](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/caffeine-benefits/) to painkillers (most often ibuprofen and Tylenol) slightly but significantly improves their effectiveness for acute pain [ [53](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6485506/), [54](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20624245/), [55](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6485702/), [56](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11999141/)]. 5. Massage Clinical research shows that massage helps reduce pain, [anxiety](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/natural-treatments-anxiety/), and [depression](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/natural-treatments-depression/) in people with pain from different conditions. However, its benefits appear to be short-lived and decline after a few weeks [ [57](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9872050/), [58](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14665792/), [59](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1490272/), [60](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14736355/)]. In a meta-analysis of over 1000 patients, massage reduced pain and anxiety associated with postoperative recovery. Massage was also found effective as an add-on to painkillers after heart surgery in a meta-analysis of 12 studies [ [61](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29173797/), [62](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28619390/)]. In a systematic review, vaginal massage in the final month of pregnancy prepared almost 2500 women for birth, reducing the likelihood of trauma and pain, increasing flexibility, and decreasing muscle and soft tissue resistance. However, massage was only effective for women who had previously given vaginal birth [ [63](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23633325/), [64](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24695503/)]. 6. Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) [Palmitoylethanolamide](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/palmitoylethanolamide-pea/), or [PEA](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/palmitoylethanolamide-pea/), is produced in the body naturally to combat pain and inflammation. Many animals and plants also produce PEA. The highest amounts can be found in soy lecithin, soybeans, egg yolk, peanuts, and alfalfa. PEA activates the anti-inflammatory [PPAR alpha](https://selfhacked.com/blog/about-ppar-alpha-and-natural-ways-to-activate-it/) while reducing the activity of the [FAAH](http://selfhacked.com/blog/the-bliss-gene-faah-snps-rs324420/) gene, which breaks down the calming cannabinoid anandamide [ [65](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5429331/)]. A decent amount of evidence backs up PEA's ability to reduce complex pain. It has been investigated in over 30 clinical trials and a total of ~6k people since the 1970s [ [66](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22845893/)]. While most of the research speaks to PEA's ability to reduce pain in general, studies often fail to make a distinction between neuropathic and non-neuropathic pain. Another limitation was that most of these studies lacked a placebo control. More high-quality research is needed to determine how effective PEA is at relieving different types of pain. In an analysis of 12 human studies, PEA supplements taken for at least 2 weeks reduced chronic and neuropathic pain intensity without any serious adverse effects [ [67](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26815246/)]. In a clinical trial on 80 people with fibromyalgia, PEA (600-1200 mg/day) as an add-on to conventional therapy reduced pain and joint tenderness when compared to the drugs alone. However, the study was poorly designed (it lacked randomization and blinding) [ [68](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4676767/)]. In 2 trials of over 100 women with endometriosis, PEA (300-400 mg/day) relieved pelvic pain and improved sexual function over 6 months [ [69](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26491823/), [70](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21601979/)]. In a small trial on 20 women, PEA (400 mg, 2x/day) in combination with transpolydatin improved the effectiveness of TENS at relieving vulvar pain [ [71](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23343704/)]. Preliminary clinical research in 30 diabetics shows that PEA (300 mg/day) reduces neuropathic pain caused by this condition [ [72](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3996286/), At high doses (600-1200 mg/day), PEA reduced carpal tunnel syndrome caused by nerve compression in 2 small trials [ [73](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21483401/), [74](https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?journal=Eur+J+Neurol&title=P1577:+The+carpal+tunnel+syndrome+in+diabetes:+clinical+and+electrophysiological+improvement+after+treatment+with+palmitoylethanolamide&author=A+Assini&author=D+Laricchia&author=R+Pizzo&volume=17&issue=S3&publication_year=2010&pages=295&pmid=19863647&)]. In a small trial on 24 people with jaw pain (temporomandibular disorders), taking PEA for 12 weeks (up to 900 mg/day) relieved pain better than ibuprofen (1800 mg/day) [ [75](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22558609/)]. In a small trial on 30 people undergoing wise tooth removal, taking PEA tablets (300 mg, 2x/day) for 15 days reduced postoperative pain [ [76](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3200278/)]. In a pivotal trial of over 600 people, PEA (300 or 600 mg/day) strongly reduced sciatic pain, higher dose having a more beneficial effect. PEA reduced pain intensity by over 50% in just 3 weeks, which is rarely seen with most painkillers. In another study, PEA improved pain in people with sciatica who didn't respond to oxycodone [ [77](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4631430/), [78](https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?journal=AMC&title=Combination+of+oxycodone+and+palmitoylethanolamide+for+low+back+pain+treatment&author=P+Desio&volume=1&issue=2&publication_year=2011&pages=62-71&)]. 7. Psychotherapy Thoughts and perception of threats may increase pain. The following mental/emotional factors can affect pain [ [79](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10954644), [80](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12071487), [81](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22115492)]: - Thoughts - Emotions - Social and familial support - Cultural background - Context and memory associated with the pain (through conditioning) Cognitive behavioral therapy improved the overall quality of life in some individuals with chronic pain, with modest effectiveness [ [82](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15599126)]. Acceptance and commitment therapy focuses on the context of how the patients feel the pain [ [83](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4788652/)]. Increasing the acceptance of the pain and the context can help reduce pain. This is most likely effective as a chronic pain management strategy [ [84](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25193001)]. Clinical hypnosis can reduce pain in adults and children, and has been observed to reduce acute pain, migraines, arthritic pain, cancer pain, and surgery pain [ [85](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18714889), [86](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2752362/)]. Insufficient Evidence The following substances have shown promise against pain in limited, low-quality clinical studies; there is currently insufficient evidence to support their use in this context, and they should never replace what your doctor prescribes. Remember to talk to your doctor before starting any new supplement or making significant changes to your diet. 8. Acupressure Acupressure is a form of TCM similar to [acupuncture](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/acupuncture-benefits-mechanisms-risks/), except that it involves the use of applied pressure in place of needles. Pressure is applied using the hands, thumbs, fingers, or devices to specific places (called acupoints) on the body. A small trial on 22 healthy women showed that acupressure might decrease the pain of needle insertion when compared to sham acupressure [ [87](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18633049/)]. In another trial on 31 cancer patients, acupressure reduced the need for [opioids](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/why-the-ice-bucket-challenge-is-so-popular-it-functions-like-heroin/) by up to 44% [ [88](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26390073/)]. In a clinical trial on 98 people with chronic migraines, acupressure enhanced the pain-relieving effects of conventional medication (sodium [valproate](https://drugs.selfdecode.com/blog/depakote/)). However, a placebo effect can't be ruled out because the control group received the medication without sham acupressure [ [89](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5502191/)]. Preliminary research suggests that acupressure improves pain and disability in people with low-back pain. However, the authors of a meta-analysis warned that the studies included were heterogeneous and had low quality [ [90](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28438274/)]. Another meta-analysis found acupressure (both self-administered and delivered by a trained person) effective at relieving menstrual pain. Again, the studies were generally of low quality and had high risk of bias [ [91](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27863617/)]. Acupressure has also been suggested to reduce pain intensity and the need for painkillers during labor. However, all the studies had low quality and high risk of bias [ [92](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21735441/)]. Studies have also found acupressure effective at reducing postoperative pain. However, the results were mixed and better-quality, large-scale studies are still needed for a more accurate estimation [ [93](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12538202/), [94](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30815805/)]. 9. Biofeedback "Biofeedback training" is a growing trend in healthcare, where people are hooked up to devices for measuring different aspects of bodily functions in order to see how these processes are taking place in real-time. People can then be trained to learn to control the way these processes are carried out [ [95](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23777436), [96](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4306760/)]. 10. Clove In a clinical trial on 73 healthy volunteers, a topical gel with clove essential oil applied on the mouth was as effective as lidocaine as an anesthetic [ [97](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16530911/)]. Similarly, a topical gel with clove and papaya prevented the pain caused by an injection in a trial on 60 children [ [98](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32611866/)]. Multi-ingredient formulations with the essential oils of clove and other herbs reduced pain from ear infections and muscle strain in 2 small trials [ [99](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23274083/), [18](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25553684/)]. 11. Lavender [Lavender](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/lavender-health-benefits/) essential oil applied topically to the insertion area of a needle reduced the intensity of the pain in 30 healthy volunteers and 34 dialysis patients [ [100](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26051566/), [101](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21854199/)]. In two studies, lavender used in an aromatherapy massage to the stomach region significantly reduced the severity of menstrual cramps. Similarly, applying 3 drops of lavender oil to the hands or a piece of cotton and inhaling it reduced abdominal pain and backache during menstruation in 2 clinical trials [ [102](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16884344/), [103](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23158705/), [104](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5405632/), [105](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24731891/)]. In a clinical trial of 47 people with migraine, the inhalation of lavender oil significantly reduced [headache](https://selfhacked.com/blog/natural-treatment-migraines/) severity [ [106](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22517298/)]. In two small trials, lavender used in an aromatherapy massage to the joints reduced pain and depression. However, the specific effects of the lavender oil itself and the massage are unknown [ [107](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15778570/), [108](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27863613/)]. In 2 clinical trials on almost 300 pregnant women with planned C-section, aromatherapy with inhaled lavender oil, as an add-on to medication, reduced pain after the procedure. Similarly, lavender oil aromatherapy reduced the need for painkillers in a trial on 48 children undergoing tonsil removal [ [109](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22235509/), [110](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31730539/), [111](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23932834/)]. 12. Licorice In a clinical trial on almost 2500 terminal cancer patients, a combination of [licorice](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/licorice/) root and peony root, along with a Taiwanese tonic vegetable soup, reduced pain better than the soup alone or regular hospital diet [ [112](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18364321/)]. 13. Vitamin D A meta-analysis of 19 clinical trials found that taking [vitamin D](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/35proven-health-benefits-vitamin-d-part-1/) supplements for 1-24 months reduces the intensity of chronic pain. However, the final follow-up pain score was similar in the vitamin D and placebo groups [ [113](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27676659/)]. In a clinical trial of almost 900 teenage girls, supplementation with high-dose vitamin D reduced pain and other [PMS](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/relieve-pms-naturally/) symptoms [ [114](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29447494/)]. In a clinical trial on 30 women with fibromyalgia and vitamin D deficiency, supplementation to maintain adequate levels of this vitamin reduced pain [ [115](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24438771/)]. The evidence for the use of vitamin D for osteoarthritis is contradictory. A trial on over 100 people found supplementation effective to reduce pain in people with vitamin D deficiency, but a longer-term study on almost 150 people found it ineffective. Based on these discrepancies, the American College of Rheumatology recommends against the use of vitamin D supplementation [ [116](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3792285/), [117](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3984919/), [118](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31908163/)]. Chronic Pain & Fibromyalgia Possibly Effective 1. Acupuncture Acupuncture is a form of alternative treatment developed by practitioners of Traditional Chinese Medicine. During acupuncture, thin metal needles are inserted at acupuncture points, or acupoints [ [119](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4458928/), [120](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22106073)]. These thin metal needles are briefly manipulated manually to penetrate the skin. The needles are then left in the skin for a period of time (30 minutes - hours). Some practitioners believe that electrical stimulation of the needle can enhance the stimulation of the acupoints [ [121](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20818865)]. Acupuncture may be effective at pain management without the side effects of opiates. It may even help patients wean off from opiate drugs [ [122](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27475042), [123](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3296192/)]. Perhaps the most common use of acupuncture is to manage chronic pain [ [124](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4036643/)]. Stimulation of acupoints is believed to release [endorphins](https://selfhacked.com/blog/endorphins/) and natural [opioids](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/why-the-ice-bucket-challenge-is-so-popular-it-functions-like-heroin/) in the body, thus reducing the perception of pain. In addition, it also reduces [stress](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/63-factors-raising-stress-cortisol-level-backed-science/) and tension [ [125](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26896946)]. However, the role of acupuncture in pain management is controversial. Some researchers have hypothesized that a combination of neural signaling, opioids, [glutamate](https://selfhacked.com/blog/glutamate/), and [adenosine](https://selfhacked.com/blog/adenosine-health-effects/) are involved [ [125](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26896946)]. 2. Cannabis According to some estimates, medical use of [cannabis](https://selfhacked.com/blog/top-6-unique-super-effective-ways-counteract-negative-performance-effects-cannabismarijuana/?utm_source=seo&utm_medium=selfhacked&utm_campaign=id00002) dates back as far as the 16th century B.C. in ancient Egypt [ [126](https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v363/n6426/abs/363215a0.html)]. Nabiximols (Sativex) is a cannabis extract formulated as a spray that contains similar amounts of [THC](https://drugs.selfdecode.com/blog/tetrahydrocannabinol-thc/) and [CBD](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/cannabidiol-cbd/) (2.7 mg THC and 2.5 mg CBD per spray). It has been approved in Canada and the UK as an add-on treatment for the symptomatic relief of neuropathic pain in adults with treatment-resistant [multiple sclerosis](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/causes-symptoms-diagnosis-risk-factors-of-multiple-sclerosis/) [ [127](https://www.mstrust.org.uk/a-z/sativex-nabiximols), [128](https://www.bayer.ca/omr/online/sativex-pm-en.pdf)]. An analysis of five small clinical studies concluded that inhaled cannabis (providing 1.6-96 mg THC daily) reduces the intensity of neuropathic pain caused by HIV, trauma, diabetes, chemotherapy, and other conditions in up to 2 weeks [ [129](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26362106?dopt=Abstract)]. In one small clinical trial, inhaled cannabis (containing 2.9% or 6.7% THC) reduced neuropathic pain due to spinal cord injury. The effect was immediate and lasted less than 2 hours [ [130](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27286745?dopt=Abstract)]. Some human studies showed mixed results regarding THC's effectiveness for other types of pain, as is the case with sunburns and capsaicin-triggered pain and inflammation in healthy volunteers [ [131](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18580179), [132](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18073554)]. Chronic pain is an occasional adverse effect of kidney transplantation. People normally manage it with painkillers, which can damage the kidneys. In a small trial on 7 people with kidney transplants, CBD was safe and reduced pain in all but one person [ [133](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29579828)]. 3. Therapeutic Baths Therapeutic baths—or balneotherapy—are sometimes used to reduce inflammation. Therapeutic baths can simply be set to a particular temperature (to trigger a heat shock response) or can have minerals added. In the case of baths in natural springs, some of the observed therapeutic effects may be due to the presence of small amounts of stressors like hydrogen sulfide or even radon [ [134](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6032246/)]. A meta-analysis found that two weeks of therapeutic mineral baths somewhat reduced pain and tenderness in people with fibromyalgia [ [135](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4227103/)]. Therapeutic baths have also been found to improve chronic pain in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and other painful disorders. Studies on balneotherapy are typically at least two weeks long, with at least daily 20 minute mineral baths [ [136](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16882592/), [137](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11344827/), [138](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28303358/)]. 4.
